title: Looking for script fonts similar to this handwriting
content:
Attached image shows a kinda handwritten 'scrawl' of a font.

I've found a fair few that come close, but not perfect.

Does anyone have a name/link to where I can get this from?

Massive thanks in advance.
author: David Heath

comments.content:
Uhh... I don't know if the attachment went through, so the link to the image displaying the font is here:

[http://www.design-portal.co.uk/temp/Font.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20130607090527/http:/www.design-portal.co.uk/temp/Font.png "http://www.design-portal.co.uk/temp/Font.png")

Cheers.

Well, This actually seems to BE handwritten.. :)

Dav, [formlos](http://web.archive.org/web/20130607090527/http:/www.formlos.net/)

That isn't a font. It's handwriting. A font is a set of shapes that repeat, unless special substitutions are made. Handwriting comes right out of a hand and a pen. That's what this is. If you need a handwriting font, search for "handwriting" on your favorite font sites.

It's definitely not actually handwritten.

At work earlier I had access to several other pictures with various other things written on them using the same font and they were all consistently shaped. There is definitely a font out there the same as this.
Can you show us the other samples? More words would be helpful in both identifying the 'font' and convincing the skeptics.
Hmmm, we'll need some serious convincing indeed, because this _definitely_ looks handwritten.

Just to state the obvious, part of the reason there's so much skepticism is due to the connector positions. This would have to be a very involved OpenType font to simulate the "random" connectors found in your sample. For example, the "on" combination connects up top, the "su" a bit lower, the "an" quite tight and lower still, and the "co" and "cy" connections are also at different levels. When drawing a script type the connectors are always drawn to a grid, at the same level, so that any character combination will "fit." Some OpenType fonts will have substitutions to create the illustion of randomness, but this sample is just too random to believe that it's a font. It has nothing to do with how "casual" the characters look, it's how they fit together that leads to the conclusion that this is actually handwriting.
Isn't it possible that the other samples you came across were handwritten by the same person, hence the consistency?

I agree with all the assertions that this is probably handwritten, but the point should be do we know of a font that looks like this. I think it looks an awful lot like a font called [Desyrel](http://web.archive.org/web/20130607090527/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/Script09Pg3.html) (forth row down). It is by Dana Rice and can be found with the [Apostrophic Lab fonts at TypOasis](http://web.archive.org/web/20130607090527/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/lab/a_d.htm).

- Mike Yanega
